author: @BerlinCB
text: I absolutely love Olay & Friends discussions.  As a progressive "old white dude", the perspective and nuance that you all bring, not only to the topics that I'm aware of and engaged in, but also ones unique to the black and brown communities, are very informative and refreshing.  It really resonated with me when you were pointing out that change can be really slow sometimes, but we have to acknowledge our successes.  That we don't have to agree with the candidate completely, but we can all agree who we have the best chance to influence towards progressive change.  My opinion is to vote Harris in and then protest the shit out of her to continue to apply pressure towards meaningful change, because with Trump we most likely wouldn't have the right to protest any longer.  Finally, several of you pointed out, that the most important thing we can all do, is to get involved in our local communities and embody the change we want to see and spread that hope and love through direct interaction and conversation with those in our communities.  Thanks for what you are all doing!

replies.author: @Mycommentmywords
replies.text:
Let me try to explain why I as a kid incorrectly thought that the only "Black" people were Black Americans. As a kid I would walk up to kids my age with skin that is Black like mine. In trying to connect with other kids my age I would ask are you Black? Which looking back was not me asking if they were Black because they clearly were. But rather me asking them do they see us as the same.

And if that kid was Jamaica they would say, " I'm not Black I'm Jamaican." Or if that kid from Haiti the kid would say, " im not Black I'm Haitian." Or if that kid was from Dominican republic they would say, " I'm not Black I'm Dominican." Etc from any Black people that either they themselves or there parents weren't born in America.

So I as a kid being told from other Black kids that they're not Black. When I could only describe myself as Black. Gave me the incorrect idea that they don't think that they are Black.

replies.author: @josl1345
replies.text: It's an interesting conversation for sure. I grew up in the Bay Area.    I always considered Black Americans to be Black. I had several Kenyan and Nigerian hair clients for several years and I considered them Kenyan and Nigerian but not Black. And they felt the same. I had a South African co-worker who,  in conversation about dating, made a point to tell me she didn't date Black men. I had an Algerian co-worker ask me if I was Black because I so quiet and mild tempered...she thought I was East African. Black always meant Black Americans to me--Afro, James Brown, etc--a distinct 'type' of Black. Obviously we are all descendants of Africa. I have since evolved and part of that is in part due to taking the time to explore the history and experiences of Black people throughout the diaspora. I have much more to learn but it's a start.

replies.author: @cardboard87
replies.text:
I'm black American. I had a coworker with parents from Haiti. He was adamant that he wasn't black despite his very dark complexion. Customers still talked to he and I the same, and said ignorant things. I always believed that does not matter in the eyes of other races, employers, and law enforcement. They see dark skin, and treat us all the same. They don't adjust their behavior based on your ancestory.

Arguing technicalities feels like it causes unnecessary division when we need to look out for each other. These systemic issues Olay brought up hurt all of us black people.

replies.author: @XeniasWorld
replies.text: @josl1345¬† is it because "black Americans" are American by default? I can understand the people you mentioned identifying according to nationality, because they're from a continent where "black" is the majority, and they distinguished themselves according to nations/tribes. Here in the states, we have always been identified by our race

author: @caitieeeee
text:
This was an excellent conversation as always, Olay! Thank you for facilitating it bc it gave me a lot to chew on.

Not to be nitpicky because thats annoying lmao but this is important re: Gaza and Palestine. It was mentioned a couple of times, and I want to push back on the idea that Palestinian activists and advocates are not engaged in the political process, I mean that's really not accurate or fair to say. and it is telling that even only referring to their demand as "ceasefire" felt to me that there may not have been a whole lot of recent engagement with the movement from that particular guest, which is his right - clearly we all have things that we prioritize, there's so much to deal with that we can't all be engaged in all things all the time. I wanted to gently point out that Palestinian American activists, while not monolithic or in agreement 100% on electoral politics like all movements, have changed the language around calling for a ceasefire because the Biden administration is using a different definition of ceasefire than what that term has meant historically for Palestinian liberation. The reason why the uncommitted vote organizers have been asking Kamala to meet is because they would prefer to support her over Trump by a wide margin, but they are trying to use leverage to get at least some sort of commitment from her on US support for this genocide. They are very much involved in the process and are strategic in how they engage.

replies.author: @olurinatti
replies.text: Nobody said Palestinian activists aren‚Äôt engaged in the political process.

replies.author: @whatsthetea9609
replies.text: It‚Äôs a tough situation and I have sympathy for their plight. It‚Äôs good there‚Äôs media attention towards this situation. There are countries that are dealing with even worse atrocities and they don‚Äôt get any coverage. I‚Äôm not saying that to compare situations. I‚Äôm just trying to find some positivity. The fact of the matter is both political parties are not for cease-fire. It was smart for KH politically to say comments suggesting that. But when she gets in office. She‚Äôll continue to do what JB did. The US is responsible for the occupation. I also feel bad for Israel.

replies.author: @caitieeeee
replies.text: @olurinatti I must have misunderstood then, my apologies.

replies.author: @caitieeeee
replies.text:
@whatsthetea9609¬† I mean I can tell you that certainly there is a wider problem with a lack of attention on the genocides in Sudan and Congo for instance. Sudanese people in particular because of being an Arabic-speaking country have to deal with anti-Black racist nonsense from the rest of the non-Black Arabic-speaking world, so you'll see people who came out the womb with a commitment to Palestinian liberation be anti-Black to Sudanese refugees who are experiencing genocide as well. So I think part of the issue is that the world is anti-Black and even though Afro Palestinians exist, the world sees Palestinians in a homogenized, racialized way (as a result of zionism) so we largely think of them as Arab, when the reality is that Palestinians are quite diverse.

I can only speak to my own experiences in pro-Palestinian spaces but there is often a plethora of flags on signs and and lots of talk about the collective struggle against colonialism and how it has caused so many atrocities worldwide and unique experiences for different peoples. The struggle is different in Congo than it is in Palestine than it is in the US but all of these have  connections and Palestinians have spoken about that a lot and done a lot of work with other liberation movements.

As far as whether or not one atrocity is worse than another, what is happening in Gaza is not any less horrific than what is happening anywhere else. 

Sorry to take up this much space on something that I misunderstood from the video, btw.

replies.text: @caitieeeee no apology necessary, I think your comment was still valuable!

replies.text: @olurinatti¬† thank you Olay, I really appreciate that - and I appreciate your work!

author: @dpj310
text:
Hello Olay, 
I really appreciate your show.  It popped up in my feed and I saw that Clay and Reese were in it and I am huge fans of theirs (met them at Beyond The Mic).  I really have an issue with the comments of @prshakur, when he says he is being asked to "choose for this Black and Asian Prosecutor...."  He is freaking angry at THAT!  At THAT moment,  I really wanted to ask him MR OHIO, what has JD Vance done for Ohio in the areas of abolition, since affects what happens in Ohio more locally?  Nevermind I know since I have family and friends in Ohio.  Since he has been in office (2023), he has not sponsored or co-sponsored ONE damn bill. JD Vance has not done a freaking thing for Ohio.  SO as far as the protest that they were in, the opponents of VP Harris wants to have the police ARREST them or make protesting ILLEGAL.  What will his abolitionist movement do for that?  I find it VERY interesting that all of these detractors from VP Harris or any Democratic candidate, has ALL type of smoke for them and NONE of the same energy for the Republicans.  You wont find any of the Gaza protesters at their rallies because 45 has already told his supporters to shut down any protestors by beating them up and he'll pay for their fines (which is a damn lie, surprise).  I knew where @prshakur stood  during he first introduction.  He said Black woman prosecutor and used it as a pejorative. I agree with your sentiments about this slave patroller injustice system but there are only two options:  1:  Burn it down completely and start anew and if there is nothing ready to go, we're still screwed especially since these white nationalists still have have the power; or 2: vote on the ones we can work with & get change the laws we can until we can't (while creating the ones we want) and then tear it down.   These folks act as if we are picking life mates, ironically since many due less diligence in choosing a partner but want all the tangibles for someone to vote for...that for the most part, they'll never meet.  We are voting for ourselves, families, and futures.   Outside of this, great discussion.

author: @outb4thecount
text:
A semi rant: I get a little frustrated and emotional when I hear folks decide not to vote when our ancestors fought and 
died for that right not so long ago. 

In attempting to put my emotions aside I‚Äôm reminded of the history of other people subjugated by systems that kept them powerless and squabbling amongst themselves. When you don‚Äôt hold the levers of power you cannot expect to make permanent change so just like our ancestors we have to get creative. We are not going to achieve ‚Äúabolition‚Äù, equity in healthcare, women‚Äôs autonomy or any other freedom without organizing locally, nationally AND changing minds. 

Politics is a dirty business, sitting in an ideological ivory tower isn‚Äôt politically savvy or solving any problems. It‚Äôs like seeing a fire and saying well it‚Äôs going to burn anyway and kill my family but at least I wasn‚Äôt involved with it.

author: @Yistherewar
text:
I think a lot of us more radical leftists are really done with any sort of system reform, but the unfortunate reality is that revolution isn't feasible yet. And it's hard to, on the one hand, feel like you're participating in systems that you know cause so much global harm, and on the other hand, to accept that substantial change isn't an option now. Revolution feels pressing when you see climate change, see people die, see people become disabled and unhoused, see almost everyone around you burned out and hopeless. But we need more time to do groundwork. We need more time to effectively organize. A Harris presidency won't fix anything, it mostly just won't hinder progress (or reverse it) as much as a Trump presidency would.
Vote, don't vote. But if you vote - don't silence or shut down legitimate criticism of the candidate or her policies, and if you don't vote - don't try to sour people on political activity (especially if they're otherwise politically apathetic). We don't have to agree on voting (or for whom) to still work together to create networks of mutual aid that will be essential regardless of what happens in the future.

replies.author: @jordanbrown3816
replies.text:
I feel like some leftists aren‚Äôt seeing the bigger picture here. I know a lot of young leftists like myself who feel really passionately and negatively about the democratic party and see that the change they want won‚Äôt happen with them as you said. That‚Äôs valid and fair, but what they don‚Äôt realize is that not voting is NOT activism. 

You can desire for change and critique democrats, but unfortunately we are stuck in this two party system. Of the two options, one of them will make the change that leftists want much harder and will actively try and reverse a lot of progressive wins in this country. 

So, when I see leftists that are adamant about not voting I believe they have this misconception that in order to be a ~true~ leftist and stick to your beliefs you mustn‚Äôt vote for a democrat‚Ä¶ when all that benefits is the Republican Party. 

It‚Äôs more about their own view of themselves than seeing the bigger picture. That in order to make change we HAVE to make the correct choice between two futures: Trump or Harris. Either way it‚Äôs going to happen so don‚Äôt just throw your vote away like it doesn‚Äôt matter. We have the power to decide which landscape we want to try and make progress in, and that should matter to anyone who can vote regardless of how you feel about either candidate.

replies.author: @melan8ed197
replies.text: Couldn‚Äôt have said it better myself

replies.author: @otherperson
replies.text: @jordanbrown3816 important to point out that plenty of people who don't vote do actually do important organizing work to achieve what they perceive to be their goals, such as unionizing their buildings and workplaces, starting up neighborhood assemblies, and doing political education in their areas. Also important to not that voting is not activism either. What the radical left should be actively doing is building power from below through intimate direct engagement with your community, and if you want to vote go vote. It takes a few hours at most and in no way detracts from your organizing.

replies.author: @sajallday
replies.text: I would argue conditions are ripe for revolution. Because it is easier to radicalize someone by helping them and showing them how the system is actively harming them. I feel like "conditions not being right right now" when there was an entire countries of enslaved/colonized people who actively fought and overthrew their oppressors is historically inaccurate. With the planet dying, that means that time is of the essence and we have to fight for the people after us. I do agree that groundwork needs to be done, but people are hesitant to start.

Theres plenty that can be done on all levels to be that driver, people need to stop making excuses. We all cant be in politics but the very least you can do is vote for people that are the least in opposition to the change you want..

replies.text: Chattel slavery in the Americas was unique in it's scale and that the condition was deemed heritable.The US slavery is unique among the Americas for the length of slavery and by extent that heritability (most other countries abolished slavery and/or heritability much earlier). author: @squillenial
text:
Just like every episode, appreciate the nuance and the willingness to take the time to clarify, correct, and reframe things as misunderstandings and disagreements happen.

Something I've found to be helpful with people arguing against [insert candidate here] for not being perfectly leftist enough is to do a "Let's Say" experiment: 

Let's say there's a candidate that's the most leftist, abolitionist, socialist, burn-it-down politician you can imagine, and let's say they win. What then? What specifically would you have them do? Not generalities like "stop cop cities", but specifics - how? With an executive order? Great! Now consider - that's a solution that lasts until a president decides they don't want it anymore. Plus, congress is not currently a majority Leftist, so most will work against it to make it ineffective. And they'll do this for every single thing that that president might try to force through via EO. 

Then next election cycle, the talking points will be about how ineffective that president has been and how bad for the country they are because congress has to "waste time" dealing with executive orders instead of their own stuff. The Perfect Leftist Candidate won't be any help in changing the legislation and systems, but they'd be a perfect target for every political commentator. 

In my experience, if people are really in it for the change and not just for something to be mad about, conversations like that will help them to realize that they're trying to build a building from the top down without a foundation in place and wondering why they feel like they're fighting a losing battle.

replies.author: @leokingjones2685
replies.text: Kamala explained statistics which prove that kids who do not get foundational education by 3rd grade continue to fall behind, get discouraged and eventually drop out of school. Stats show that this group is more likely to commit crimes, thus jail/prison. Therefore, she put this policy in place in order to reduce this outcome. If parents do not feed their children or take them to the doctor for needed medical attention, then it is considered "child neglect" with possible charges. Therefore, why should a child's educational needs be any different?  This policy was for extreme truancy and I am apt to believe there would have been some discretion between a 6yr old being habitually truant vs a 16yr old who is ditching school.  10 yrs ago, my grandson was 6 yrs old, but his mother had not put him in school. I registered him in school near me and kept him during the week to make sure he went to school.  I did this because I did not want him to fall behind. He is currently an A student, plays violin and sings in his high school choir. He was also voted President one year.  Had he not been in school, as law requires, then his chances at avoiding the criminal justice system would have greatly diminished.

replies.author: @adrians-ro8kk
replies.text: @otherperson "that song has nothing to do with Drake's race" This is pure gaslighting. A huge chunk of the discussion was calling him a colonizer and culture vulture. Rick Ross spent half his song calling him "white boy". SAYING it (and the overall attempted take down of Drake) wasn't about his race is an outright lie. Republicans are using the EXACT same talking points they have seen online about Drake, on Kamala. People don't want to admit it.

replies.author: @diddy2612
replies.text: @otherpersonpart of it was centered on his race

replies.author: @otherperson
replies.text: @diddy2612 give me a single line from Not Like Us that references Drake's race or skin color.

replies.author: @otherperson
replies.text: @adrians-ro8kk in your defense of the belief that Not Like Us is partially about Drake's race, you reference another person not in the song, another song, and accusations of being a culture vulture and colonizer, which are things that anyone can do and take part in. His point about Drake is that, despite not living a hard life, despite being a middle class canadian, who grew up in whiteness and called black Toronto slang "ignorant", Drake uses the aesthetics, slang, and stereotypes of African American culture to portray himself as someone who he is not. As other people always point out, if it was about race Kendrick would not have called Adonis "a black man" and would have similarly come at J Cole. The song makes no reference to Drake's race at all, nor his skin color, and only talks about how he treats rappers in Atlanta who he allegedly uses to gain credibility. The song is not about race, and it's not good to try to use the language of "gas lighting" when talking about something this trivial and obviously unrelated.

replies.author: @otherperson
replies.text: @adrians-ro8kk you may not have realized this, but Rick Ross is not, in fact, Kendrick Lamar.

replies.text: @adrians-ro8kk do you think that only white people are capable of being colonizers and culture vultures? I complain using the same talking points when talking about k pop groups who use the aesthetics of African American culture as a persona. Are they suddenly white or are people of color not allowed to call other people of color culture vultures if they commodify the aesthetics of a culture they are not a part of?

replies.author: @wonder-witch
replies.text:
And if you really have a hard time finding it within you to use your vote, look around and see if there‚Äôs a person in your life (felons, immigrants, etc) that cannot vote and wishes they could. Ask them what they think and vote in their stead. 

I live in Texas and had friends who weren‚Äôt very politically inclined and fairly privileged and when they found out I couldn‚Äôt vote bc I wasn‚Äôt a citizen, they would do it for me. When 2016 was happening and Clinton and Trump were both PEAK unlikeable candidates, they asked me how I felt bc they thought both were both were weirdos. I said Clinton. It didn‚Äôt matter that they hated her, they voted in my stead anyway. And even tho 2016 still went down the way it went down, I‚Äôll never forget that they did SOMETHING with their dissatisfaction with politics that wasn‚Äôt just throwing away their vote, and the thing they did wasn‚Äôt about them and their discomfort.

replies.author: @leokingjones2685
replies.text: A loss for Dems is a win for Trump, the MAGA movement, White Christian Nationalist, White Supremist,  & Project 2025. This is not the election to try to send a message to Dems.  Amongst other issues is the Supreme Court. Trump has already placed 3 judges on the Supreme court, all of whom were recommended by the folks behind Project 2025 (The Heritage Foundation). There are at least 2 justices who are near death or retirement. We CAN NOT allow Trump to replace them. Further, the President appoints Federal Judges. We can not allow Trump to continue rigging the court system. This is how his classified docs case got dismissed. He previously appointed the judge that ended up on that case.  The Supreme Court has been chipping away at the constitution and they are not finished.  They have ruled that Corporations are people, Presidents have absolute immunity, State officials can take bribes, They overturned the Chevron document, and they overturned part of the Civil Rights Act, which previously protected the Black vote. There was also a recent ruling that will result in some of the Jan 6  prisoners being freed. You may be aware of all of this already.  Therefore, we need  Kamala (Democrat) to win. The others can not win. The Supreme Court will shape this country for our children, grandchildren and generations to come. We can not let Republicans replace Supreme Court Justices and appoint federal judges. We need to crush Trumpism.

text:
Great podcast! Refreshing to find this kind of discussion.  But why didn't you properly challenge the idea of abolishing criminalisation/the police? Are there no crimes he thinks should be criminalised or punished?? Abolish the Police movement was always clearly a wedge issue to cause conflict in the community. It speaks to a bigotry of low expectation, like even basic accountability... And the fact that Americans are seemingly unable to see any possible solutions to problems which uniquely effects America. In other countries it isn't the nom to expect that a person might be killed if you call the police on them. And no other countries have such glorification and proliferation of gun violence.
